A character in armor riding a horse, holding a spear and a shield, appearing to be in motion. He drew up at Alice’s side, and tumbled off his horse just as the Red Knight had done: then he got on again, and the two Knights sat and looked at each other for some time without speaking. Alice looked from one to the other in some bewilderment. He is also known as the White Knight, who mistakenly wore the Knight's helmet, causing a mix-up and a humorous situation.

A horse being ridden by the White Knight, depicted in mid-stride. The horse is the mount of the Red Knight, involved in the action of the story as it stops suddenly and the Knight tumbled off. They let them get on and off them just as if they were tables!
A large tree with detailed bark and branches, providing a backdrop to the scene. The tree is the place where Alice hides to be out of the way of the blows during the knights' battle.

An old-fashioned lantern held by the White Knight.
It’s meant for plum-cake, said Alice. The dish is the object on which the plum-cake was placed, mentioned as evidence that Alice was not dreaming.

And he hung it to the saddle, which was already loaded with bunches of carrots, and fire-irons, and many other things. The bag is used by the Knight to carry various items, including the dish meant for plum-cake. There are so many candlesticks in the bag.

‘Yes, it’s a very good bee-hive,’ the Knight said in a discontented tone, ‘one of the best kind. But not a single bee has come near it yet. And the other thing is a mouse-trap. I suppose the mice keep the bees out––or the bees keep the mice out, I don’t know which.’ The bee-hive is an object fastened to the saddle, which the Knight hopes will attract bees for honey. The Mouse-trap is an object carried by the Knight, intended to catch mice that might disturb the bees.

‘To guard against the bites of sharks,’ the Knight replied. ‘It’s an invention of my own. And now help me on. I’ll go with you to the end of the wood——What’s that dish for?’ ‘It’s meant for plum-cake,’ said Alice. The Anklets are objects around the horse's feet, invented by the Knight to guard against shark bites.
